item.title: Oil Climbs as Israel-Iran Conflict Amps Up Risks: Markets Wrap
item.description: Oil climbed early Monday with investors squarely focused on escalating geopolitical tensions as Israel and Iran continue to bombard each other with no sign of a pause.

item.description: Oil jumped at the start of the week after Israel and Iran continued attacks on one another’s territories over the weekend, raising concerns an escalation could disrupt crude supply from the Middle East.

item.title: Japan's Kato on JGBS, Foreign Investors
item.description: Japan’s Finance Minister said that discussions with market participants is a key factor in making sure that government bonds are bought and sold stably, as the ministry neared a closely watched gathering with investors. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: New World Faces Key Test With Bond Interest Payment Due Monday
item.description: New World Development Co., the distressed Hong Kong developer that’s unsettled investors by delaying some debt payments, faces a critical test Monday when interest comes due on a dollar bond.
item.dc:creator: Trista Xinyi Luo, Pearl Liu

media:content.media:description: Prospective buyers look at a model of the Deep Water Pavilia project, developed by New World Development Co., in Hong Kong, China, on Saturday, June. 7, 2025. New World launched a luxury residential project on the south side of Hong Kong Island at a record low price as the embattled developer aims to accelerate property sales amid debt concerns.

item.title: Global Rate Limbo Reigns After 150 Days of Trump
item.description: Multiple central banks are set to keep interest rates frozen in the coming week while continuing to gauge the impact of trade disruptions instigated by US President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: The Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve building in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, Aug. 21, 2024. Chair Jerome Powell will usher in the next chapter in the Federal Reserve's inflation battle on Friday, when he's expected to set the table for an interest-rate cut while reassuring investors that policymakers can stave off a sharp economic slowdown.

item.title: Fed on Hold Leaves Wall Street Asking What It Will Take to Cut Interest Rates
item.description: With Federal Reserve officials signaling an extended hold on interest rates, investors and economists will look to Chair Jerome Powell this week for clues on what might eventually prompt the central bank to make a move, and when.

item.title: Bond Investors Look to Fed for Guidance on Timing of Rate Cuts
item.description: Treasuries investors whipsawed by President Donald Trump’s trade and fiscal policies will this week glimpse the impact on the Federal Reserve’s interest-rate policy.
item.dc:creator: Ye Xie

media:content.media:description: Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, speaks during the Federal Reserve IF 75TH Anniversary Conference in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, DC, US, on Monday, June 2, 2025. US President Donald Trump pushed Powell to lower interest rates at their first in-person meeting since the president's inauguration last week, the White House said.

item.title: US Ex-Im Bank May Fund Greenland Rare Earths Mine, Reuters Says
item.description: The US Export-Import Bank is considering providing up to $120 million for a rare earths project by Critical Metals Corp. in Greenland, Reuters reported Sunday, citing a letter of interest.
item.dc:creator: Sam Kim (News)

media:content.media:description: Fishing boats and small vessels at the port in Sisimiut, Greenland, on Monday, March 31, 2025. US President Donald Trump has so far had limited success with his advances as most Greenlanders don't want to join the US, even as they want increased independence from Denmark.

item.title: Traders Dive Into Options Market as Geopolitical Risk Flares
item.description: Israel’s air strikes on Iran, followed by the Islamic Republic’s retaliation, rippled through markets Friday, prompting traders to pile into options for protection amid ongoing questions of long the conflict can last.
item.dc:creator: David Marino, Mia Gindis

media:content.media:description: Damage to a building hit by a ballistic missile launched from Iran in Bat Yam, Israel, on Sunday, June 15, 2025. Israel and Iran continued intense bombardments on one another’s territories for the third day, with no sign of a reprieve and growing concerns over a wider conflict in one of the world’s key oil-producing regions.

item.title: Hungary Nominates Palotai as Central Bank Deputy Governor
item.description: Hungary nominated Daniel Palotai to become the fourth deputy governor of the central bank, a position created this month after Parliament passed an overhaul of the institution’s leadership.

media:content.media:description: Daniel Palotai, chief economist at the National Bank of Hungary, arrives for dinner during the Jackson Hole economic symposium, sponsored by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, in Moran, Wyoming, U.S., on Thursday, Aug. 23, 2018. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's debut address to the Wyoming gathering of central bankers this week will do little to shake financial markets if history is any guide.

item.description: Former Credit Suisse investment banker Joachim Ringer is joining German mid-cap focused private equity firm Vorsprung Management as a partner.
item.dc:creator: Eyk Henning

A global trade war is heating up and Germany’s biggest seaport, like the country at large, is steeling itself for what may be to come. Photographer: Maria Feck/Bloomberg

item.title: Nigeria’s Dangote Refinery Offers Credit Facilities to Marketers
item.description: Nigerian billionaire Aliko Dangote’s 650,000-barrel-a-day plant said on Sunday it will now offer a credit facility to some dealers in an effort to boost supply in Africa’s most populous country.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Olurounbi

media:content.media:description: Gasoline storage tanks at the Dangote Industries Ltd. oil refinery and fertilizer plant site in the Ibeju Lekki district of Lagos, Nigeria, on Monday, May 22, 2023. Aliko Dangote, Africa’s richest person, announced the opening of a mega refinery in Nigeria — seven years late — to a backdrop of skepticism about how fast it will really be able to ramp up.

item.title: Egypt Leads Mideast Stock Losses Amid Strikes; Israel Rebounds
item.description: Most Middle Eastern markets dropped on Sunday as investors signaled growing concerns of a wider conflict amid tit-for-tat attacks by Israel and Iran.

Israel’s annual inflation stood at 3.5% as of October, above the government’s target range of 1% to 3%, largely due to supply-side constraints. Photographer: Kobi Wolf/Bloomberg

item.title: Traders ‘Hold Their Nerve’ to Ride Bumpy Emerging Market Rally
item.description: Investors are betting the months-long rally in emerging markets has further to run even as tariff threats and escalating geopolitical tensions signal a rocky path ahead.

item.title: Trump’s Executive Order to Make Flying Cars a Reality
item.description: On the heels of President Trump’s recent executive order, we explore the fast-emerging world of flying cars, or eVTOLs, as companies like Joby Aviation and Pivotal race to bring personal air travel to life. Joby is working toward FAA certification for air-taxi services in cities, with plans to launch in 2026, while Pivotal is focused on lightweight, personal aircraft for consumers, public safety, and defense. Despite regulatory and technological hurdles—especially around batteries and infrastructure — the hope is to make flying as accessible as and more efficient than driving. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Mediobanca May Delay Shareholder Vote on Banca Generali Bid
item.description: Mediobanca called a board meeting on Sunday to decide whether to postpone an investor meeting to endorse its plan to takeover Banca Generali SpA, according to people familiar with the situation, who asked not to be identified while discussing private information.
item.dc:creator: Sonia Sirletti, Tommaso Ebhardt, Antonio Vanuzzo

media:content.media:description: A Mediobanca SpA bank branch in Milan, Italy, on Tuesday, April 29, 2025. Mediobanca has a surprise takeover bid for the private banking arm of Assicurazioni Generali SpA.

item.title: Gundlach Is Latest to Sound Corporate Debt Alarms: Credit Weekly
item.description: DoubleLine Capital has its lowest-ever allocations to speculative-grade bonds now, because valuations just don’t reflect the risks.
item.dc:creator: Ethan M Steinberg

media:content.media:description: Jeffrey Gundlach, chief executive officer and chief investment officer of DoubleLine Group, during the Bloomberg Global Credit Forum in Los Angeles, California, US, on Wednesday, June 11, 2025. The world's credit markets are having a moment, but trade wars, persistent inflation and growing concern of a slowdown in the world's largest economy loom large.

item.title: Ecuador Expected to Delay Fee on Mining, Industry Says
item.description: Ecuador has indicated that it will consider delaying the implementation of a new mining fee estimated to generate $229 million annually, according to Rodrigo Darquea, vice president of the country’s mining chamber.
item.dc:creator: Stephan Kueffner

media:content.media:description: The entrance to the Bira mine in Zaruma, Ecuador, on Thursday, April 28, 2022. Illegal mining has polluted waterways and sinkholes are swallowing the colonial houses of Zaruma, an Ecuadorian town that was literally built on gold and aspires to be a UNESCO world heritage site.

item.title: Tim Walz Speaks on Minnesota Democrats Assassination
item.description: Minnesota Governor Tim Walz held a press conference on the assassination of two democratic Minnesota state lawmakers and their spouses who were shot Saturday. Walz said it was likely a targeted political attack by a suspect impersonating a police officer. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Nigeria’s Central Bank Halts Dividends, Bonuses for Some Banks
item.description: The Central Bank of Nigeria has ordered banks under regulatory forbearance to halt dividend payments, director bonuses, and foreign investments.
item.dc:creator: Emele Onu

media:content.media:description: Automobiles drive past the headquarters of the Nigerian central bank in Abuja, Nigeria, on Friday, Jan. 10, 2020. Revenue in Nigeria has fallen short of the government target by at least 45% every year since 2015, and shortfalls have been funded through increased borrowing.

item.title: Russia, China to Lead Construction of Two Kazakh Nuclear Plants
item.description: Kazakhstan has selected Russia’s Rosatom to lead a consortium for the construction of its first nuclear power plant. The China National Nuclear Corp. expected to be lead a group to build a second atomic facility.

media:content.media:description: Workers do welding on a part of a RITM-200 nuclear reactor at ZiO-Podolsk Machine-Building Plant, an enterprise of Russia's nuclear agency Rosatom machine-building unit, in the town of Podolsk in the Moscow region on Dec. 5, 2023.

item.title: Retailers Seen Using Stablecoins to Push Back Against Card Fees
item.description: Stablecoins have become one of the hottest buzzwords in the world of finance as of late with US lawmakers on the cusp of passing the first guidelines for mainstream use of the cryptocurrencies designed to mirror the dollar.
item.dc:creator: Emily Mason

media:content.media:description: A customer enters their pin number while making a chip and pin payment using a Visa Inc. payment card, via a Verifone Systems Inc. payment device at a restaurant in London, U.K., on Friday, May 22, 2015. Credit and debit cards that can be used by tapping the reader are gaining users, and mobile apps are set to further boost the popularity of contactless paying.

item.title: Johnson & Johnson CEO: 'We’re in the Golden Era of Medical Innovation'
item.description: Johnson & Johnson Chairman and CEO Joaquin Duato believes that we are now in a “golden era” of innovation, particularly in the United States. Venture capital plays a vital early-stage role, but big pharma provides the infrastructure and market access. We visit Johnson & Johnson's innovation facility in Spring House to see how its early-stage innovation ecosystem serves patients and the local economy. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: ‘Golden Era’ of Medication Meets Geopolitical Uncertainty
item.description: In this episode of Wall Street Week, we talk to a longtime diplomat and the CEO of Johnson & Johnson
item.dc:creator: David Westin

media:content.media:description: Joaquin Duato, chief executive officer of Johnson & Johnson, during a taping of Bloomberg Television's Chief Future Officer episode in Raritan, New Jersey, US, on Thursday, June 6, 2024. With J&J spinning off its consumer products division, their chief financial officer now helps lead a company entirely focused on innovative medicine and medical technology, requiring the deployment of billions in research and development, as well as strategic M&A.
